data.text: Is CrankTank4 Worth the Money?
Do any of you lovely people own a cranktank? If so, are they worth it?
Absolutely worth it if riding in hot places!
data.author: Alison Wormell

data.text: *with limited water refill places
data.author: Alison Wormell

data.text: I rode the south downs way yesterday and only found 3 of the taps, I'm thinking of getting one and keeping it on until the colder weather kicks in
data.author: Chris Roberts

data.text: Yeah if you like! I mean, the handling of the bike is what's the best part of the crank tank here üôÇ I think of them in terms of desert riding in Australia, here I'd just strap a couple of nalgenes to the forks or if running a rack, to the struts running down to the rear wheel axle because I wouldn't run it all the time here.
data.author: Alison Wormell

data.text: my rack and forks both have mounts, I might do as you say and just put extra bottles on
data.author: Chris Roberts

data.text: yeah, probably best! Wouldn't do it on a carbon fork offroad personally but it's totally worth it - although if you don't already have bottles/voile straps that might obviously cost you a little initially too.
data.author: Alison Wormell

data.text: I'll stick them on the rack then, I have carbon forks. Unfortunately, I ride my bikes like they have suspension
data.author: Chris Roberts

data.text: I‚Äôve thought of a Cranktank too‚Ä¶. Think they do a 3 litre too now.But for the SDW I‚Äôd only take 1 bottle next time (but do know where the taps are üòé).
data.author: Dave Pegler

data.text: Without sounding silly. But wjats a crank tank?
data.author: Chris Martin

data.text: 4 litre water tank that takes less frame space as 2 bottles
data.author: Chris Roberts

data.text: ooooooh might have a look at that

data.text: it's ¬£90 so I wanna know it's worth it before hitting the buy button

data.text: I have one I‚Äôm selling as it doesn‚Äôt fit my current bike. Great kit, weight low down and out of the way so doesn‚Äôt impact on pedalling.
